title: FYP Project
text:

Role: Automation Developer & Business Analyst
Team: 4-member cross-functional team (Business Users, IT, Compliance)

title: FYP Project
text:
Organization: Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) - Insurance Department
Duration: June 2022 - December 2022 (6 months internship)
Role: Automation Developer & Business Analyst
Team: 4-member cross-functional team (Business Users, IT, Compliance)



The Insurance Department manually validated 1,200+ monthly regulatory submissions from 80+ insurance companies. Each submission required: - 45-60 minutes of manual checking - Cross-referencing against 15+ data sources - Compliance with 7 different regulatory frameworks - Monthly total: 900+ human-hours with 8-12% error rate



I designed and implemented a comprehensive Python-based automated validation system employing a rule-based validation engine that transformed the entire regulatory compliance workflow. The solution was architected around three core theoretical frameworks:

title: FYP Project
text:
1. Modular Validation Architecture
The system was built on a modular validation architecture where each regulatory requirement was encapsulated as an independent validation module. This followed the Single Responsibility Principle from software engineering, allowing each validation rule to be developed, tested, and maintained independently. The architecture enabled:

Rule Isolation: Each MAS Notice requirement (e.g., solvency ratios, premium accuracy thresholds, claims reporting standards) became a standalone validation module
Parallel Development: Multiple team members could work on different regulatory modules simultaneously
Hot-swappable Updates: New MAS regulations could be added without disrupting existing validation workflows

title: FYP Project
text:
2. Multi-Source Data Integration Framework
I implemented a unified data integration framework that created a single source of truth by harmonizing data from 15+ disparate sources. The framework employed:

Data Normalization Algorithms: Standardized varying data formats from different insurance companies into a common schema
Temporal Alignment Techniques: Synchronized data across different reporting periods and fiscal calendars
Reference Data Management: Created a master reference database for cross-validation against authoritative sources like IRAS tax data, ACRA corporate records, and MAS‚Äôs internal regulatory database

title: Data Visualization: Insurance Claims Analysis Dashboard
text:
Context: During my Financial Business Informatics diploma at Temasek Polytechnic (Year 3, Semester 2), I undertook a Capstone Project with a major Singaporean insurer. The project aimed to analyze 3 years of motor insurance claims data to identify patterns and optimize premium pricing strategies.
Course: FIN3201 - Business Intelligence & Analytics
Duration: 4-month industry project
Team: 3 students + 2 industry mentors
Dataset: 45,000+ motor insurance claims (2019-2021) worth SGD 120+ million
The Challenge: The insurer‚Äôs pricing team relied on static Excel reports that showed basic aggregates (total claims, average cost) but couldn‚Äôt reveal: 1. Temporal patterns (seasonal, weekly, hourly trends) 2. Geographic hotspots for accidents 3. Vehicle-specific risk profiles 4. Correlations between multiple variables
My task was to create an interactive dashboard that transformed raw claims data into actionable insights for their actuarial team.

title: Data Visualization: Insurance Claims Analysis Dashboard
text:
Context: During my Financial Business Informatics diploma at Temasek Polytechnic (Year 3, Semester 2), I undertook a Capstone Project with a major Singaporean insurer. The project aimed to analyze 3 years of motor insurance claims data to identify patterns and optimize premium pricing strategies.
Course: FIN3201 - Business Intelligence & Analytics
Duration: 4-month industry project
Team: 3 students + 2 industry mentors
Dataset: 45,000+ motor insurance claims (2019-2021) worth SGD 120+ million
The Challenge: The insurer‚Äôs pricing team relied on static Excel reports that showed basic aggregates (total claims, average cost) but couldn‚Äôt reveal: 1. Temporal patterns (seasonal, weekly, hourly trends) 2. Geographic hotspots for accidents 3. Vehicle-specific risk profiles 4. Correlations between multiple variables
My task was to create an interactive dashboard that transformed raw claims data into actionable insights for their actuarial team.

title: Data Visualization: Insurance Claims Analysis Dashboard
text:
Visualization Rationale & Design Decisions

Why an Interactive Dashboard?
Traditional static charts (bar, line, pie) failed to show the multi-dimensional relationships in the data. I chose a dashboard approach with linked visualizations because:

Multi-variable Analysis: Claims data has 15+ dimensions (time, location, vehicle type, driver age, weather, etc.)
Exploratory Nature: Different stakeholders needed different views (actuaries vs.¬†operations vs.¬†marketing)
Drill-down Capability: From high-level trends to individual claim details
Comparative Analysis: Side-by-side comparison of different segments



Chart Selection Rationale








Chart Type
Purpose
Data Encoded




Heat Map
Show geographic accident hotspots
Location coordinates, claim frequency, claim severity


Time Series Chart
Show temporal patterns
Date/time, claim count, average cost


Sunburst Diagram
Hierarchical breakdown
Vehicle type, Make, Model, Age


Scatter Plot Matrix
Correlation analysis
6 key variables simultaneously


Parallel Coordinates
Multi-dimensional profiling
8+ risk factors per claim

title: Data Visualization: Insurance Claims Analysis Dashboard
text:

title: Reflection
text: Throughout the development of this Quarto website portfolio, I actively utilized ChatGPT (specifically DeepSeek) as my primary GenAI tool. This reflection documents my experience, insights, and lessons learned about integrating artificial intelligence into academic and creative work.

title: Reflection
text: Throughout the development of this Quarto website portfolio, I actively utilized ChatGPT (specifically DeepSeek) as my primary GenAI tool. This reflection documents my experience, insights, and lessons learned about integrating artificial intelligence into academic and creative work.

title: Reflection
text:
üõ†Ô∏è Why I Chose ChatGPT/DeepSeek
Accessibility & Context Understanding: I selected ChatGPT because it demonstrated exceptional understanding of technical documentation (Quarto, R, Markdown) while maintaining conversational clarity. Unlike specialized coding assistants, it could help with everything from YAML configurations to content creation and troubleshooting.
Comprehensive Support: The tool provided end-to-end assistance: - Technical implementation (Quarto website setup) - Content generation (project narratives) - Code debugging (R visualization errors) - Design suggestions (website structure) - Learning explanations (Markdown syntax)
